critters.name: White-tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser often seen near fields and feeders.
critters.fact: White-tailed deer use their bushy tails to signal danger by flashing the white underside as a warning.

critters.name: Black Bear
critters.summary: Largest forest mammal in Michigan woodlands.
critters.fact: Black bears have an excellent sense of smell, helping them find food from miles away.

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Adaptable predator common in rural areas.
critters.fact: Coyotes can adapt to urban areas, often scavenging for food around cities and suburbs.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary hunter active in open woods and fields.
critters.fact: Red foxes use their bushy tails for balance and to keep warm in cold weather.

critters.name: Gray Fox
critters.summary: Smaller fox species able to climb trees.
critters.fact: Gray foxes are unique for their ability to climb trees, unlike most other North American foxes.

critters.name: Bobcat
critters.fact: Bobcats have excellent night vision, helping them hunt effectively in the dark.

critters.name: Porcupine
critters.fact: Porcupines canâ€™t shoot quills; their sharp quills detach only when touched by predators.

critters.name: Beaver
critters.fact: Beavers have orange teeth that never stop growing and stay strong from chewing wood all day!

critters.name: Muskrat
critters.summary: Small aquatic rodent near ponds and streams.
critters.fact: Muskrats build dome-shaped lodges from plants, similar to beavers but smaller and less complex!

critters.name: Mink
critters.fact: Minks are excellent swimmers, using their webbed feet to hunt fish and aquatic prey underwater.

critters.name: Fisher
critters.fact: Fishers use their sharp claws to climb trees and catch prey like squirrels and birds.

critters.name: River Otter
critters.summary: Playful aquatic predator found near rivers.
critters.fact: River otters can hold their breath underwater for up to 8 minutes while diving for food!

critters.name: Eastern Gray Squirrel
critters.fact: Eastern Gray Squirrels can remember hundreds of hidden nut locations using spatial memory!

critters.name: American Red Squirrel
critters.fact: American Red Squirrels fiercely defend their spruce cone food caches year-round to survive harsh winters.

critters.name: Chipmunk
critters.summary: Ground squirrel known for cheek pouches.
critters.fact: Chipmunks have cheek pouches to carry food, helping them gather snacks quickly and store them safely!

critters.name: Snowshoe Hare
critters.summary: Forest rabbit with seasonal coat change.
critters.fact: Snowshoe hares change fur color seasonally for camouflage: brown in summer, white in snowy winter.

critters.name: Eastern Cottontail
critters.fact: Eastern Cottontails can hop up to 10 feet in a single leap to escape predators!

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.fact: Raccoons are excellent climbers and have five nimble fingers on each hand, like tiny human hands!

critters.name: Opossum
critters.fact: Opossums are immune to snake venom, including rattlesnakes and cottonmouths!

critters.name: Striped Skunk
critters.summary: Night forager known for defensive spray.
critters.fact: Striped skunks can spray a foul-smelling liquid up to 10 feet to deter predators.

critters.name: Flying Squirrel
critters.fact: Flying squirrels glide by stretching a flap of skin called a patagium between their legs.

critters.name: Little Brown Bat
critters.fact: Little Brown Bats use echolocation to catch insects mid-air, helping control mosquito populations naturally!

critters.name: Big Brown Bat
critters.fact: Big Brown Bats use echolocation to navigate and catch insects in total darkness.

critters.name: Barred Owl
critters.summary: Woodland owl known for 'who cooks for you' call.
critters.fact: Barred Owls are known for their distinctive â€œWho cooks for you?â€ call echoing through forests at night.

critters.name: Great Horned Owl
critters.fact: Great Horned Owls have specialized feathers allowing nearly silent flight to sneak up on prey at night.

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold feeder visitor with loud calls.
critters.fact: Blue Jays can mimic hawk calls to scare away other birds and protect their territory.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Northern Cardinals are one of the few birds where both males and females sing beautifully.

critters.name: Black-capped Chickadee
critters.fact: Black-capped Chickadees can remember hundreds of hiding spots for their food during winter!

critters.name: Tufted Titmouse
critters.fact: Tufted Titmice use their crests to communicate mood, raising them when excited or alert.

critters.name: White-breasted Nuthatch
critters.summary: Tree climber often moving headfirst down bark.
critters.fact: White-breasted nuthatches can walk headfirst down tree trunks to find hidden insects and seeds!

critters.name: Downy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Downy Woodpeckers use their stiff tail feathers as a prop while climbing tree trunks.

critters.name: Hairy Woodpecker
critters.fact: Hairy Woodpeckers drum on trees to find insects hidden beneath the bark for a tasty meal!

critters.name: Pileated Woodpecker
critters.fact: Pileated woodpeckers drum loudly to mark territory and create nesting cavities in large dead trees.

critters.name: Red-bellied Woodpecker
critters.fact: Red-bellied Woodpeckers drum to communicate and mark territory using their strong, chisel-like beaks.

critters.name: Mourning Dove
critters.fact: Mourning Doves can fly up to 55 miles per hour to escape predators!

critters.name: American Goldfinch
critters.fact: American Goldfinches molt twice yearly, changing bright yellow summer feathers to duller winter plumage.

critters.name: Dark-eyed Junco
critters.fact: Dark-eyed Juncos are often called "snowbirds" because they appear during winter across much of North America.

critters.name: House Finch
critters.fact: House Finches are known for their cheerful warbling songs, which males use to attract mates.

critters.name: Purple Finch
critters.fact: Purple Finches sing sweet, musical songs to mark their territory and attract a mate during spring.

critters.name: Wild Turkey
critters.summary: Large ground bird common in Michigan.
critters.fact: Wild turkeys can run up to 20 miles per hour to escape predators.

critters.name: Ruffed Grouse
critters.summary: Forest bird known for drumming display.
critters.fact: Ruffed Grouse create drumming sounds by rapidly beating air with their wings to attract mates.

critters.name: Sandhill Crane
critters.summary: Tall wetland bird with loud call.
critters.fact: Sandhill Cranes perform unique, graceful dances to strengthen pair bonds and communicate with each other.

critters.name: American Crow
critters.fact: American Crows use tools and can recognize human faces, showing impressive intelligence in the bird world!

critters.name: Common Raven
critters.fact: Common Ravens can mimic sounds, including human speech, showcasing impressive intelligence and adaptability in the wild.

critters.name: Red-tailed Hawk
critters.fact: Red-tailed Hawks have excellent eyesight, spotting prey from over a mile away while soaring high!

critters.name: Cooperâ€™s Hawk
critters.fact: Cooperâ€™s Hawks are amazing flyers, known for swift maneuvers through dense trees when hunting.

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallard ducks can sleep with one eye open to stay alert for predators!

critters.name: Wood Duck
critters.summary: Colorful duck nesting in tree cavities.
critters.fact: Wood Ducks are expert tree nesters, often hatching eggs in tree cavities near water.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.fact: Canada Geese can fly thousands of miles during migration using a distinctive V-formation for energy efficiency.

critters.name: Great Blue Heron
critters.fact: Great Blue Herons can stand still for minutes, patiently hunting fish with their sharp, spear-like beaks!

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.fact: Painted turtles can live over 30 years and absorb oxygen through their skin underwater!

critters.name: Snapping Turtle
critters.fact: Snapping turtles can live over 30 years and have powerful jaws to catch prey and defend themselves!

critters.name: Bluegill
critters.fact: Bluegill sunfish can breathe air by gulping it at the waterâ€™s surface when oxygen is low.

critters.name: Largemouth Bass
critters.fact: Largemouth bass can grow up to 20 inches long and are popular freshwater sport fish.

critters.name: Yellow Perch
critters.fact: Yellow Perch have sharp spines on their fins that help protect them from predators!

critters.name: Northern Pike
critters.fact: Northern Pike have sharp teeth and use ambush tactics to catch prey quickly in freshwater habitats.

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog with loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Spring Peepers are tiny frogs known for their loud, high-pitched mating calls heard in early spring.

critters.name: American Bullfrog
critters.fact: American Bullfrogs can jump over 3 feet, making them impressive amphibian athletes in the wild!

critters.name: Green Frog
critters.fact: Green frogs get their name from the greenish color on their backs and legs.

critters.name: Leopard Frog
critters.fact: Leopard frogs can jump over 5 feet, using their powerful legs to escape predators quickly!

critters.name: Garter Snake
critters.fact: Garter snakes can swim and are often found near water, using their stripes as camouflage.

critters.name: Water Snake
critters.fact: Water snakes can breathe underwater by holding air in their lungs for up to an hour!

critters.name: Eastern Milk Snake
critters.fact: Eastern Milk Snakes mimic venomous snakes with their bright patterns to avoid predators.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarch butterflies migrate up to 3,000 miles, traveling from North America to central Mexico each year!

critters.name: Swallowtail Butterfly
critters.fact: Swallowtail butterflies have colorful tails that mimic predator antennae to confuse enemies.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly up to 30 miles per hour and hover like helicopters while hunting prey!

critters.name: Damselfly
critters.fact: Damselflies fold their wings along their body, unlike dragonflies that hold wings open at rest.

critters.name: Firefly
critters.fact: Fireflies use chemical reactions in their abdomens to create their iconic, blinking greenish-yellow light!

critters.name: Honeybee
critters.fact: Honeybees communicate by dancing to share locations of tasty flowers with their hive friends!

critters.name: Bumblebee
critters.fact: Bumblebees vibrate their wings to release pollen, a technique called â€œbuzz pollination.â€

critters.name: Grasshopper
critters.fact: Grasshoppers can jump over 20 times their body length using powerful hind legs!
